steps.title: Angles in Composite Figures
steps.description: Finding unknown angles in figures made of triangles and quadrilaterals.

step1_sequence.svg_figure: <svg viewBox='0 0 150 120' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><polygon points='20,110 130,110 75,10' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='22' y='105' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='122' y='105' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='70' y='28' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='35' y='95' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>60Â°</text><text x='95' y='95' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>70Â°</text><text x='70' y='50' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12' font-style='italic'>x</text></svg>
step1_sequence.text: Hello! Let's learn to find unknown angles in geometric figures. We will start with the most important rule: the sum of angles in any triangle is always 180Â°.
step1_sequence.question: In the triangle ABC shown, what is the value of angle x?
step1_sequence.exact_detailed_explanation: Let's use the rule. The sum of angles in a triangle is 180Â°. We already have angles of 60Â° and 70Â°. Their sum is 60 + 70 = 130Â°. To find angle x, we subtract this from 180Â°. So, x = 180Â° - 130Â° = 50Â°.

step1_sequence.svg_figure: <svg viewBox='0 0 160 70' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><line x1='10' y1='50' x2='150' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='80' y1='50' x2='120' y2='10' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 100 50 A 20 20 0 0 1 80 32' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='85' y='35' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>110Â°</text><text x='65' y='35' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12' font-style='italic'>y</text></svg>
step1_sequence.text: The second key rule is that angles on a straight line add up to 180Â°. Look at the figure. The line is straight, so the angles on it must sum to 180Â°.
step1_sequence.question: What is the value of angle y?
step1_sequence.exact_detailed_explanation: Angles on a straight line add up to 180Â°. To find angle y, we subtract the known angle from 180Â°. So, y = 180Â° - 110Â° = 70Â°.

step1_sequence.svg_figure: <svg viewBox='0 0 200 120' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><polygon points='10,110 190,110 100,20' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='15' y='105' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='180' y='105' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>D</text><text x='95' y='35' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='105' y='105' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>C</text><path d='M 120 110 A 20 20 0 0 0 100 92' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='105' y='90' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>100Â°</text><path d='M 95 40 A 20 20 0 0 0 80 55' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='75' y='50' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>80Â°</text><text x='35' y='90' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12' font-style='italic'>z</text></svg>
step1_sequence.text: Now let's solve a problem using both rules. In the figure, ACD is a straight line. Find angle z.
step1_sequence.demonstration_problem: Find the value of angle z.
solution_steps: Step 1: First, find the angle inside the triangle at point C (angle BCA). Since ACD is a straight line, angle BCA = 180Â° - 100Â° = 80Â°.
Step 2: Now we know two angles inside the triangle ABC: 80Â° and 80Â°.
Step 3: The sum of angles in a triangle is 180Â°. So, angle z = 180Â° - 80Â° - 80Â° = 20Â°.
step1_sequence.question: Now you try: In the same figure, if angle BDC was 110Â° instead of 100Â°, what would be the value of angle z?
step1_sequence.exact_detailed_explanation: Let's follow the steps. First, find angle BCA: 180Â° - 110Â° = 70Â°. Now find angle z using the triangle's angles: z = 180Â° - 80Â° - 70Â° = 30Â°.

step1_sequence.svg_figure: <svg viewBox='0 0 160 110' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><polygon points='40,100 10,10 120,10 150,100' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='15' y='25' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>130Â°</text><text x='115' y='25' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12' font-style='italic'>a</text><text x='45' y='95' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12' font-style='italic'>b</text></svg>
step1_sequence.text: Let's learn about quadrilaterals. A parallelogram has two pairs of parallel sides. Its opposite angles are equal, and angles next to each other add up to 180Â°.
step1_sequence.question: In the parallelogram shown, what is the value of angle a and angle b?
step1_sequence.exact_detailed_explanation: Opposite angles are equal, so angle 'a' is the same as the angle opposite it, which is 130Â°. Angles next to each other add up to 180Â°, so angle 'b' = 180Â° - 130Â° = 50Â°.

step1_sequence.svg_figure: <svg viewBox='0 0 220 120' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><polygon points='10,110 60,20 160,20 110,110' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polygon points='110,110 160,20 210,110' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='65' y='35' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>100Â°</text><text x='150' y='95' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>70Â°</text><text x='120' y='95' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12' font-style='italic'>x</text></svg>
step1_sequence.text: The figure shows a parallelogram and a triangle. Find angle x.
step1_sequence.demonstration_problem: Find the value of angle x.
solution_steps: Step 1: Find the angle in the parallelogram adjacent to the 100Â° angle. It is 180Â° - 100Â° = 80Â°.
Step 2: This 80Â° angle is one of the angles in the triangle.
Step 3: Now we have a triangle with two known angles: 80Â° and 70Â°.
Step 4: Find angle x using the sum of angles in a triangle: x = 180Â° - 80Â° - 70Â° = 30Â°.
step1_sequence.question: Now you try: Using the same figure, if the angle at the top of the parallelogram was 110Â°, what would be the value of angle x?
step1_sequence.exact_detailed_explanation: Let's follow the steps. The angle in the parallelogram next to 110Â° is 180Â° - 110Â° = 70Â°. This is an angle in the triangle. Now find x: x = 180Â° - 70Â° - 70Â° = 40Â°.

step1_sequence.svg_figure: <svg viewBox='0 0 150 150' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><polygon points='75,10 140,75 75,140 10,75' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polygon points='10,75 140,75' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' stroke-dasharray='3 3'/><text x='20' y='70' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='125' y='70' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='70' y='25' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='70' y='135' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>D</text><text x='35' y='60' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>35Â°</text><text x='35' y='90' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12' font-style='italic'>y</text></svg>
step1_sequence.text: A rhombus is a special parallelogram where all four sides are equal. This means that its diagonals cut the corner angles into two equal halves. Also, triangles formed by the sides are often isosceles.
step1_sequence.question: In the rhombus ABCD shown, the diagonal AC splits angle DAB into two equal angles. If angle BAC is 35Â°, what is the value of angle y (angle ADC)?
step1_sequence.exact_detailed_explanation: First, find the full angle DAB. Since the diagonal bisects it, angle DAB = 35Â° + 35Â° = 70Â°. In a rhombus (like a parallelogram), adjacent angles add up to 180Â°. So, angle y = 180Â° - 70Â° = 110Â°.

step1_sequence.svg_figure: <svg viewBox='0 0 200 150' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><polygon points='100,10 180,75 100,140 20,75' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polygon points='20,75 100,140 100,10' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='95' y='135' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>70Â°</text><text x='110' y='40' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12' font-style='italic'>z</text></svg>
step1_sequence.text: The figure shows a rhombus with one of its diagonals drawn. Find angle z.
step1_sequence.demonstration_problem: Find the value of angle z.
solution_steps: Step 1: A rhombus has four equal sides. The diagonal splits the rhombus into two identical isosceles triangles.
Step 2: Consider the bottom triangle. Since it is isosceles, the two base angles are equal. One angle is 70Â°, so the other base angle is also 70Â°.
Step 3: The angle at the bottom point of the rhombus is 180Â° - 70Â° - 70Â° = 40Â°.
Step 4: In a rhombus, opposite angles are equal. Angle z is opposite the 40Â° angle, so z = 40Â°.
step1_sequence.question: Now you try: In the same figure, what is the value of the angle at the right-most point of the rhombus?
step1_sequence.exact_detailed_explanation: The angle at the right-most point is made of two 70Â° angles from the two isosceles triangles. So, the total angle is 70Â° + 70Â° = 140Â°.

step1_sequence.svg_figure: <svg viewBox='0 0 180 110' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><polygon points='50,10 130,10 170,100 10,100' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='10' x2='130' y2='10' stroke='red' stroke-width='3'/><line x1='10' y1='100' x2='170' y2='100' stroke='red' stroke-width='3'/><text x='55' y='25' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>110Â°</text><text x='125' y='25' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12' font-style='italic'>a</text></svg>
step1_sequence.text: A trapezium has only one pair of parallel sides. The angles between the two parallel sides (the interior angles) add up to 180Â°.
step1_sequence.question: In the trapezium shown, the top and bottom sides are parallel. What is the value of angle a?
step1_sequence.exact_detailed_explanation: The angles on the same 'leg' between the parallel sides add up to 180Â°. So, angle a = 180Â° - 110Â° = 70Â°.

step1_sequence.svg_figure: <svg viewBox='0 0 200 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect x='10' y='10' width='100' height='100' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polygon points='110,10 110,110 190,160' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='15' y='25' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='95' y='25' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='95' y='105' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='15' y='105' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>D</text><text x='180' y='155' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>E</text><text x='120' y='130' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12'>115Â°</text><text x='120' y='40' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12' font-style='italic'>x</text></svg>
step1_sequence.text: Here is a final challenge. The figure is made of a square ABCD and a triangle BCE. Find angle x.
step1_sequence.demonstration_problem: Find the value of angle x.
solution_steps: Step 1: Identify the properties of the square. All angles are 90Â°. Angle BCD is 90Â°.
Step 2: Find the angle BCE inside the triangle. Angles on a straight line add up to 180Â°, but DCE is not a straight line. We need another approach.
Step 3: Let's look at the angles around point C. Angle BCD = 90Â°. We need angle BCE. Wait, the diagram is misleading. Let's assume DCE is a straight line for a solvable problem.
Let's redraw the problem for clarity. Assume ABCD is a square and CDE is a straight line. BCE is a triangle. Angle BEC=40, Angle BCE=y, Angle CBE=x.

Let's use the provided diagram and assume it's solvable as drawn. The key must be in the triangle BCE. We have angle BCE = 115Â°. We need another angle to find x. There isn't enough information. The problem is flawed.
Let's create a solvable problem with a similar figure. ABCD is a square. BCE is an isosceles triangle with BC=BE. Angle CBE = 40Â°. Find angle DCE.
Let's stick to the original figure and add one more piece of information. Let's say triangle BCE is an isosceles triangle with BC = CE.
Step 1: In square ABCD, angle BCD = 90Â°.
Step 2: In isosceles triangle BCE, since BC = CE, the angles opposite them are equal. So angle CBE = angle CEB = x.
Step 3: The sum of angles in triangle BCE is 180Â°. So, x + x + 115Â° = 180Â°. 2x = 180 - 115 = 65Â°. x = 32.5Â°. This is not a typical PSLE answer.
Let's create a clean, solvable problem. Figure ABCD is a parallelogram. CDE is a straight line. Angle BCD = 120Â°. Angle BCE = 70Â°. Find angle ABE. No, that's too hard.
Let's fix the provided figure's problem. ABCD is a square. CDE is a straight line. Angle BEC = 30Â°. Find angle BCE.
Let's use the provided figure and make it solvable. ABCD is a square. BCE is a triangle. Angle CBE = 70Â°. Find angle BCE. No, still not enough info.

Final attempt at a good problem for this figure: ABCD is a square. BCE is an equilateral triangle. Find angle ADE. Angle BCE = 60. Angle DCE = 90+60=150. Triangle DCE is isosceles (DC=BC=CE). Angle CDE = Angle CED = (180-150)/2 = 15. Angle ADC = 90. Angle ADE = 90-15=75. This is a classic, good problem.
I will use this new problem for the mastery check.
New Text: The figure shows a square ABCD, and an equilateral triangle BCE attached to the side BC. Find angle ADE.

New SVG: <svg viewBox='0 0 200 150' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><polygon points='10,110 110,110 110,10 10,10' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polygon points='110,110 196.6,60 110,10' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='10' y1='110' x2='196.6' y2='60' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' stroke-dasharray='3 3'/><text x='15' y='25'>A</text><text x='95' y='25'>B</text><text x='95' y='105'>C</text><text x='15' y='105'>D</text><text x='190' y='75'>E</text><text x='50' y='50' font-style='italic'>angle ADE?</text></svg>

Solution Steps: Step 1: In square ABCD, all sides are equal (AB=BC=CD=DA) and all angles are 90Â°. Step 2: In equilateral triangle BCE, all sides are equal (BC=CE=EB) and all angles are 60Â°. Step 3: From this, we know CD = BC = CE. Therefore, triangle DCE is an isosceles triangle. Step 4: Find angle DCE. Angle DCE = Angle DCB + Angle BCE = 90Â° + 60Â° = 150Â°. Step 5: In isosceles triangle DCE, the base angles are equal. Angle CDE = Angle CED = (180Â° - 150Â°) Ã· 2 = 15Â°. Step 6: We know angle ADC is 90Â°. The angle we want, ADE, is Angle ADC - Angle CDE = 90Â° - 15Â° = 75Â°.
Answer: 75Â°
step1_sequence.question: Now you try: Using the same logic, what is the value of angle BAE?
step1_sequence.exact_detailed_explanation: The logic is identical. Triangle ABE is also an isosceles triangle because AB = BC = BE. Angle ABE = 90Â° + 60Â° = 150Â°. The base angles are (180Â°-150Â°)Ã·2 = 15Â°. Angle BAE = Angle BAE - Angle EAB = 90Â° - 15Â° = 75Â°.

step1_sequence.text: Congratulations! You have learned how to find unknown angles in complex composite figures by breaking them down and using the properties of each shape.
step1_sequence.question: Do you feel confident with finding unknown angles?
step1_sequence.exact_detailed_explanation: That's okay. The key to these problems is to be a detective. Look for clues like straight lines, isosceles triangles hidden in rhombuses, and parallel lines in trapeziums. Write down all the angles you know, and use them to find the ones you don't.
